Class: Snaps

snaps. Snaps

new Snaps(game, canvasID, settings)

The main class of the game engine
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
game Object A game object
canvasID String The ID of a canvas on the page to render into
settings Object <optional>
 Assorted settings to control the engine behavior.

Members

Button :Function

The Button constructor is exposed here for general use, although you may wish to define UI via a definition file and load it via Panel.load

MinHeap :Function

The MinHeap constructor is exposed here for general use.

Panel :Function

The Panel constructor is exposed here for general use.

PathFinder :Function

The PathFinder constructor is exposed here for general use.

ProximityTracker :Function

The ProximityTracker constructor is exposed here for general use.

Stats :Function

The Stats constructor is exposed here for general use. To access standard running stats you probably want stats instead.

stats :Object

Exposes some standard running stats

tweens :Object

The contents of the animate/tween module is exposed here for general use.

util :Object

The contents of the util/* modules are exposed here for general use.

util :Object

The contents of the util/* modules are exposed here for general use.

Methods

actioning(action) → {Boolean}

Test the keyboard to see if the user has pressed any bound keys
Parameters:
Name Type Description
action String The name of the action to test
Returns:
True if pressed.
Type
Boolean

addLayer(name, type, opts, idx)

Insert a new layer
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
name String A unique name for the new layer
type String The layer plugin to instantiate
opts Object <optional>
 Options to pass to the plugin
idx Number The layer index to insert it at

bindKeys(keybinds)

Call this to bind keys to actions which you can test later on with the actioning method. 
sn.bindKeys([
    {key:'left',  action:'left'},
    {key:'right', action:'right'},
    {key:'up',    action:'up'},
    {key:'down',  action:'down'},

    // alternatives
    {key:'w', action:'up'},
    {key:'a', action:'left'},
    {key:'s', action:'down'},
    {key:'d', action:'right'}
]);
Parameters:
Name Type Description
keybinds Array An array of objects exposing key and action properties. See the description for an example.

checkTimer(name, resetMs) → {Boolean}

Checks to see if a timer set with markTime has passed.
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
name String The name of the timer to check.
resetMs Number <optional>
 If omitted, the timer will be removed. If present, the timer will be reset, adding resetMs to its current expired trigger time.
Returns:
true if the timer has triggered. Note that an immediate call to checkTimer again will return false - The true value is only returned once unless the timer is reset.
Type
Boolean

cls(col)

Clears the screen. Normally you don't need to do this if your map has no holes in it since the screen will be redrawn from corner to corner.
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
col String <optional>
 The screen clearing color as a CSS color spec. Defaults to black.

createCamera(name, type, opts) → {Object}

Create a new camera for use in game. Creating a camera does not activate it. You need to then call switchToCamera.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the camera so that you can refer to it again.
type String The name of the camera plugin to instantiate.
opts Object Options to pass to the camera
Returns:
The new camera.
Type
Object

createCollider(type, opts) → {Object}

Create a new collider for use in sprites.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
type String The name of the collider plugin
opts Object Options to pass to the collider
Returns:
A collider
Type
Object

createComposite(x, y, id, endCallback)

Spawn a new composite in the world
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
x Number The world x coordinate.
y Number The world y coordinate.
id String A unique ID so you can find the composite again.
endCallback Object <optional>
 Once the composite and all its child sprites expire, this is called.

createPhaser(name, opts)

Spawn a new phaser for use in sprite updates
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
name String The name of the phaser plugin to instantiate.
opts Object <optional>
 Optional values passed to the phaser.

createTaskQueue(maxFrameTime) → {Object}

Adds a new task queue. You can add task objects to this queue. Tasks are run in a time-contrained prioritised way in the game loop.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
maxFrameTime Number The maximum time permitted for this queue to run in during each frame.
Returns:
A queue object.
Type
Object

drawImage(im, x, y)

If your game object exposes a preloadImages property, then those images will be preloaded by the engine along with the map images. Call this method to draw the image by name, e.g. 
game.preloadImages = {
    logo: 'mylogo.png'
}
//...
sn.drawImage('logo', 50, 30);
Parameters:
Name Type Description
im String The image name
x Number The screen x position
y Number The screen y position

drawWorld()

Call from your game draw function to draw the map, sprites, layers, fx etc

fx(name, opts)

Spawn a new fx instance
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
name Number The fx plugin to instantiate
opts Object <optional>
 Options to pass to the plugin

getNow() → {Number}

The current frame time, updated at the start of each loop
Returns:
The current frame time.
Type
Number

getTile(layer, c, r) → {Object}

Get a tile by it's row and column position in the original map data.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
layer Object The layer to search for tiles.
c Number The column, aka x position in the data.
r Number the row, aka y position in the data.
Returns:
A Tile, or null if the input was out of range.
Type
Object

getTilePropsAtTilePos(prop, x, y) → {String}

Get a tile property from a tile column and row in the original map data. Starts at the topmost map layer and world down to the ground.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
prop String The property to get
x Number The x tile column position
y Number The y tile row position
Returns:
The property or undefined.
Type
String

getTilePropsAtWorldPos(prop, x, y) → {String|Array}

Get a tile property from a world position. Starts at the topmost map layer and world down to the ground.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
prop String | Array The property or properties to get.
x Number The x world position
y Number The y world position
Returns:
The property value, or undefined if not found. If the prop parameter was an array, the return value will be an object describing all the properties required.
Type
String | Array

getTilePropsAtWorldPos(props, x, y)

Sets multiple properties on the topmost tile at a given tile position.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
props Object An object containing all the properties to copy into the tile's properties.
x Number The x tile column position
y Number The y tile row position

getTileWorldPos(c, r) → {Object}

Get a tile by it's row and column position and find the world position of its center point.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
c Number The column, aka x position in the data.
r Number the row, aka y position in the data.
Returns:
A tile, or null if the input was out of range.
Type
Object

getWorldEdges() → {Object}

Gets an object describing the pixel limits of the world edges.
Returns:
Contains 4 properties, le, te, re and be which hold the left, top, right and bottom edges respectively.
Type
Object

markTime(name, time)

Marks a time in the future for a timer to trigger. Timers are not events driven by the engine, but rather need to be explicitely checked in a timely fashion by the game, via checkTimer.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String A name for the timer. Use this to check the timer later.
time Number When to set the timer for in ms. E.g. 1000 == 1s in the future.

mouseScreenPos(out)

Get the mouse screen position
Parameters:
Name Type Description
out Array An 2-length array that will recieve the xy values of the mouse position in that order.

mouseWorldPos(out)

Get the mouse world position
Parameters:
Name Type Description
out Array An 2-length array that will recieve the xy values of the mouse position in that order.

registerCameraPlugin(name, fn)

Registers a new camera plugin. See other plugin code for an example of how to call this.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the plugin.
fn Function The constructor of the camera object.

registerColliderPlugin(name, fn)

Registers a new collider plugin. See other plugin code for an example of how to call this.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the plugin.
fn Function The constructor of the collider object.

Registers a new effect plugin. See other plugin code for an example of how to call this.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the plugin.
fn Function The constructor of the fx updater object.

Registers a new layer plugin. See other plugin code for an example of how to call this.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the plugin.
fn Function The constructor of the layer updater object.

registerPhaserPlugin(name, fn)

Registers a new phaser plugin. See other plugin code for an example of how to call this.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the plugin.
fn Function The constructor of the phaser object.

registerSpriteUpdater(name, ctor)

Registers a new updater plugin. See other plugin code for an example of how to call this.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the plugin.
ctor Function The constructor of the sprite updater object.

resizeCanvas()

Call this when the canvas is resized in the browser.

screenToTilePos(x, y, out) → {Number}

Takes a screen position and tells you what tile it lies on. Take care with the return value, the function signature is all backwards.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
x Number A screen x position
y Number A screen y position
out Array A 2-length array that will recieve the tile x/y position in its 0/1 values.
Returns:
The distance from the given screen position to the closest tile edge, capped at 127px.
Type
Number

screenToWorldPos(out)

Convert a screen position to a world position
Parameters:
Name Type Description
out Array An 2-length array that will recieve the xy values of the position in that order.

scroll(dx, dy)

Scroll the map view by a given amount of pixels.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
dx Number The number of pixels to scroll horizontally
dy Number The number of pixels to scroll vertically

scrollTo(x, y)

Sets the map position to center on a given world coordinate.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
x Number The x position of the new map center.
y Number The y position of the new map center.

spawnSprite(defName, stateName, x, y, h, opts)

Spawn a new sprite in the world
Parameters:
Name Type Argument Description
defName String The name of the sprite definition to use. These are set up in your game's spriteDefs data.
stateName String The initial state. This too is defined in the sprite's definition, in your game's spriteDefs data.
x Number The world x coordinate. Can be a function which takes no parameters and returns a number.
y Number The world y coordinate. Can be a function which takes no parameters and returns a number.
h Number The height off the ground. Can be a function which takes no parameters and returns a number.
opts Object <optional>
 Optional sprite parameters. For a list of parameters see the opts parameter on the Sprite class constructor.

sprite(sprite) → {Object}

Find a sprite on the stage by ID
Parameters:
Name Type Description
sprite String The name of the sprite to get.
Returns:
A sprite, or undefined
Type
Object

spriteCount() → {Number}

Count the sprites on the stage, including those in composites
Returns:
The number of sprites on the stage.
Type
Number

switchToCamera(name)

Switch to a previously created, named camera
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name String The name of the camera

worldToScreenPos(out)

Convert a world position to a screen position
Parameters:
Name Type Description
out Array An 2-length array that will recieve the xy values of the position in that order.

worldToTilePos(x, y, out) → {Number}

Takes a world position and tells you what tile it lies on. Take care with the return value, the function signature is all backwards.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
x Number A world x position
y Number A world y position
out Array A 2-length array that will recieve the tile x/y position in its 0/1 values.
Returns:
The distance from the given world position to the closest tile edge, capped at 127px.
Type
Number
